lines.text: ERT/HRT Expert Forums
Mechanisms Underlying the Early Cardiovascular Effects of ERT/HRT
Menopause is associated with many adverse effects on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk
factors in women (de Aloysio et al, 1999; Mosca, 1998). Estrogen replacement therapy has been
shown to favorably influence many of these risk factors (Mendelsohn & Karas, 1999; Scarabin et
al, 1994; Espeland et al, 1995) and biological evidence that estrogen plays a role in preventing
CVD is compelling. Despite this biological plausibility and supporting evidence from
epidemiological studies, data from confirmatory clinical trials are lacking
To date, the only published, large-scale, randomized control trial that has evaluated the
impact of HRT on clinical cardiovascular events-The Heart and Estrogen/Progestin
Replacement Study (HERS)-found no overall effect of 4.1 years of estrogen plus
medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA) on risk for MI or fatal CHD events (Hulley et al, 1998).
Surprisingly, there were significantly more CHD events in year 1 in the treatment group
compared to placebo, possibly suggesting an "early," adverse effect of HRT in some women.
The data from HERS are consistent with an analysis of women participating in the Nurses
Health Study, which showed an increased risk of CHD among women with existing CHD using
HRT (Whitehead & Stampfer, 1998), and with results from the Estrogen Replacement and
Atherosclerosis (ERA) trial (Herrington, 2000). The ERA study found no beneficial effect of
ERT or HRT on the angiographic progression of atherosclerosis after an average of 3.2 years of
treatment. Interestingly, post hoc analysis from HERS demonstrated fewer CHD events in the
HRT group in years 3 through 5 compared to placebo, suggesting an anti-atherogenic effect of
HRT after the first few years of treatment. It is also important to note that HERS was conducted
among an older, high-risk population, thus the results may not be applicable to primary
prevention of CHD events or atherosclerosis among healthy, younger postmenopausal women.
Potential explanations for an early adverse effect of ERT include procoagulant and/or
pro-inflammatory mechanisms that are not fully established. HRT has been shown to increase
levels of C-reactive protein, a marker of inflammation that is predictive of future cardiovascular
events (Ridker et al, 1999; 2000). Orally administered estrogen also activates some coagulation
pathways (Caine et al, 1992; Scarabin et al, 1997). However, research suggests that the risk of
thromboemboli with HRT use in healthy, younger postmenopausal women with no history of
thromboemboli is low, in part because orally administered estrogen therapy lowers PAI-1
activity in most women, thus increasing fibrinolysis (Koh et al, 1999). This effect may not occur
in some women, especially those with risk factors for hypercoagulability, and activation of
coagulation by estrogen may not be balanced by fibrinolysis activation (Koh et al, 1999).
Although the authors of the HERS study report speculated that the overall null result was
due to mitigation of the beneficial effect of ERT with MPA, numerous investigations have noted
beneficial effects of MPA on cardiovascular parameters. Most recently, a randomized, crossover
trial found significant increases in HDL cholesterol and vasodilator responses even with
continuous MPA (2.5 mg/d) (Herrington et al, 1999).
Clearly, the role of ERT and HRT in modifying cardiovascular risk is complex. More
research is needed to clarify the reasons for the unexpected findings in HERS and the proper role
of ERT/HRT in women with or at risk for heart disease.
